title: Practice Exercise
description:
Build a **City Distance Calculator** that uses tuples for coordinates and calculates distances between cities. **Requirements:** - Create a dictionary of cities with tuple coordinates (latitude, longitude) - Include at least 5 major cities - Display all cities with their coordinates - Ask user to select two cities - Calculate the distance between them using the Haversine formula (provided) - Show which city is further north (higher latitude) - Show which city is further west (more negative longitude) - Return results as a tuple: (distance, north_city, west_city) **Example Output:** 
=== City Distance Calculator ===

Available cities:
1. New York: (40.7128, -74.0060)
2. Los Angeles: (34.0522, -118.2437)
3. Chicago: (41.8781, -87.6298)
4. Houston: (29.7604, -95.3698)
5. Phoenix: (33.4484, -112.0740)

Select first city (1-5): 1
Selected: New York (40.7128, -74.0060)

Select second city (1-5): 2
Selected: Los Angeles (34.0522, -118.2437)

Results:
  Distance: 2451.3 miles
  Further north: New York
  Further west: Los Angeles
**Haversine Formula (provided):** 
import math

def calculate_distance(coord1, coord2):
    lat1, lon1 = coord1
    lat2, lon2 = coord2
    
    # Convert to radians
    lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2 = map(math.radians, [lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2])
    
    # Haversine formula
    dlat = lat2 - lat1
    dlon = lon2 - lon1
    a = math.sin(dlat/2)**2 + math.cos(lat1) * math.cos(lat2) * math.sin(dlon/2)**2
    c = 2 * math.asin(math.sqrt(a))
    
    # Earth radius in miles
    r = 3956
    
    return c * r
